content.description: Pull up, clip a bolt and make some balance moves, the crux, and then continue up the face to the anchor.
content.protection: Bolts to a bolt and chain anchor.
content.location: Go left around the corner from the usual longer face routes.  Rap the route.

content.description: Start just to the left of 5.8 Variation. Easy moves take you to a reachy first bolt. Clip it and complete some technical movement on slab (trust your feet!) to the second bolt. Trend up and right to some jugs and a crack where you can slot a green (0.75) Camelot. After another body length, a small pocket made an excellent home for a small nut. Trend up and left to the anchors.
content.protection: Two quick draws and an assortment of small gear. Something for the anchors.
content.location: The second route from the right, just past the arching crack.

climbs.name: No Holds Barred
climbs.fa: Karl Kiser, Deb Evans & Noah Monagle, Winter 2015

content.description:
The crux is above the third bolt but the climbing is a bit thinner to get the third clip.  Follow the weakness of the climb, the climb doesn't simply follow straight up the bolt line. 

  This climb allows easy access to the top of Corner Block where ropes can be placed for the hard, less well protected, face climbs to the left.
content.location: Start on the right end of Corner Block, cross the variation crack and follow bolts to a new anchor down and right of the old anchor.

content.description: 7 bolts to chains. crux is first three bolts with a couple engaging moves at the top

The crux is a little tricky to do cleanly, but it's great fun. It is located near  the top of the route at the beginning of the bulge. There are great handholds and footing in some places and none in others but the difficulty is sustained.
content.protection: Bolts but the route can be toproped after a scramble on the back of the block.

content.description: Start at an arching and somewhat detached looking block on the rightmost end of the formation. Climb to the top of the block then follow the rightward arching crack up and to its end. The crux comes toward where the crack ends. After solving it, climb left to the top of the block and to the anchors.
content.protection: Gear, nuts and a few cams to #2". Something to clip into the summit anchors.
content.location: See the rightward arching crack at the right side of the formation.

content.description:
At the very left end of the Red Wall, detached, is a shorter block with 5 short routes on it. The routes start on technical, slabby terrain and top out on vertical to slightly overhanging rock.   

  The routes can be either led (though some will feel fairly run-out) or top-roped, and the first four share the same anchor. The top anchors can be accessed by climbing the back of the block.
